header_summary:
The Bitcoin Development Mailing List has been a platform for various innovators, including /dev /fd0 and Jose Storopoli, to introduce and discuss advancements aimed at enhancing Bitcoin's infrastructure and privacy. /dev /fd0's discussion on the experimental rust implementation of joinstr, which aims to improve the development of coinjoin applications, invites collaboration and testing from developers interested in privacy tools ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CALiT-Zp2mb9yGrup=MGUP6xiOvV-uxoWT23fkwMi2yw2F3=EBg@mail.gmail.com/T/#u#m4d4e06bb5baa4b70a396253d13265106ced292d5)). Meanwhile, Jose Storopoli introduces the Bitcoin Output Script Descriptor (BOSD), a novel specification with a Rust implementation that streamlines on-chain withdrawals for Bitcoin Layer 2 solutions, ensuring compliance with standard transaction rules and enhancing the ecosystem's reliability ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/94ac8f66-1627-4526-bb34-095361a30fb4n@googlegroups.com/T/#u#mfe81791c5159867a73965164ac552f23d76dbd5c)).

Ariard and morehouse delve into the technical and social challenges within the cryptocurrency development community. Ariard highlights the difficulty in reaching social consensus on covenant mechanisms due to varied implementation ideas, stressing the need for a high-quality technical archive to unify and progress discussions ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/bitcoin-forking-guide/1451/2)). Morehouse discusses the nuances of a sink attack against a graph centered on the acinq node, revealing the complexities of reputation manipulation and the potential for disproportionate damage through strategic routing, underscoring the necessity for improved mitigation strategies ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/hybrid-jamming-mitigation-results-and-updates/1147/8)).

Lastly, ajtowns announces the new release of Bitcoin Inquisition 28.1, which integrates features from Bitcoin Core 28.1 and supports proposed consensus changes to enhance transaction flexibility and network consensus mechanisms. This release demonstrates ongoing efforts to refine Bitcoin's operational framework, highlighting the community's commitment to evolving the cryptocurrency's technology ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/bitcoin-inquisition-28-1/1445)).

recent_posts.title: Rust library for joinstr (coinjoin implementation)
recent_posts.summary:
- Pythcoiner shared rust joinstr library insights for coinjoin app development on Twitter.
- The library is experimental, seeking developer feedback for privacy tools.
- Communication for further discussion is welcomed via email or simplex chat.

recent_posts.title: Announcing Bitcoin BOSD: Standardized Withdrawal Output Specification for L2s
recent_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin Output Script Descriptor enhances on-chain withdrawals for Bitcoin L2 solutions.
- BOSD aims for withdrawal outputs to be standard by design, improving transaction processing.
- It offers a standardized approach to minimize ecosystem fragmentation and enhance interoperability.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Forking Guide
recent_posts.summary:
- The programming community faces challenges with cryptocurrency covenants and consensus.
- A high-quality technical archive is needed for progress, currently hindered by memoryless debates.
- Initiatives like the Bitcoin Contracting Primitives Working Group seek to organize and document proposals.

recent_posts.title: Hybrid Jamming Mitigation: Results and Updates
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion highlights a method to manipulate reputation before a sink attack on the acinq node.
- It suggests attackers send maximum endorsable payments to themselves post-reputation build-up for mitigation.
- Concerns are raised about uncompensated intermediate nodes and the potential for escalated damage through extended routing.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Inquisition 28.1
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Inquisition 28.1 integrates features from Bitcoin Core 28.1, available for download.
- It introduces backported support for ephemeral dust, enhancing transaction relay capabilities.
- The release supports consensus changes like BIP 119, enhancing Bitcoin's transaction flexibility.

active_posts.title: Reiterating centralized coinjoin (Wasabi & Samourai) deanonymization attacks
active_posts.summary:
- Vulnerabilities in Wasabi & GingerWallet and CoinJoin protocols pose deanonymization risks.
- Critical flaws allow malicious coordinators to deanonymize transactions, undermining privacy guarantees.
- Economic incentives and poor practices in protocol design fail to prevent privacy breaches and financial thefts.

active_posts.title: Update on the Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine Poinsot highlights ongoing efforts to enhance Bitcoin's security and efficiency.
- The revised proposal introduces updates to mitigate vulnerabilities and enhance protocol functionality.
- A draft Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) is underway, aiming to fortify the network against threats.

active_posts.title: Proposal for Quantum-Resistant Address Migration Protocol (QRAMP) BIP
active_posts.summary:
- The QRAMP aims to protect Bitcoin from quantum computing by transitioning to new addresses.
- It sets a firm timeline to ensure complete and timely migration, addressing various risks and uncertainties.
- Feedback is sought on GitHub to refine this quantum-resistant initiative and secure Bitcoin's future.

active_posts.title: How to linearize your cluster
active_posts.summary:
- Optimizing transaction clusters is vital for processing in cryptocurrency networks.
- Advanced linearization involves sorting transactions by fee rates and optimizing separable groups.
- The current implementation shows practical application of these concepts, despite slight theoretical divergences.

active_posts.title: Emulating OP_RAND
active_posts.summary:
- The proposed method emulates randomness in Bitcoin transactions using a trustless game, avoiding Bitcoin's script limitations.
- It employs cryptographic techniques for a fair outcome, illustrated by the Thimbles Game, without altering Bitcoin's protocol.
- This approach enables fair, decentralized applications requiring randomness without external updates or oracles.

active_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
active_posts.summary:
- The proposed BIP aims to make Bitcoin quantum-resistant by updating its signature algorithm.
- It marks the beginning of efforts to develop a "QuBit" soft fork, enhancing Bitcoin's security against quantum threats.
- The proposal is open for public review, seeking feedback to refine and validate the quantum-resistant measures.

today_in_history_posts.title: Request for a new BIP number (and discussion): Improved HD wallet generation.
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Jona proposed a new HD wallet methodology, modifying BIP32 for improvement.
- He seeks feedback and help to enhance the BIP's security.
- Jona asks for guidance on the BIP drafting process, acknowledging his linguistic flaws.

today_in_history_posts.title: Routing and explicit trust
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The paper questions the terms "channel counterparty" and "clearinghouse" and their associated risks.
- It explores trust issues in selecting intermediaries and the risks of channel opening.
- The author contrasts this with the traditional banking system's way of minimizing exposure risk.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Investment strategies include passive methods like storing cash and active involvement like developing land.
- Passive investing creates societal problems, including asset mismanagement and potentially lower asset demand if abandoned.
- The blog proposes stabilizing economies with a dual-currency system, balancing inflationary and deflationary currencies.
